column2: A man can do nothing he is not fit to do.--See! did I not tell you Mara would do her part?
column3: A man can do nothing he is not fit to do.--See! did I not tell you Mara would do her part?

column2: I looked whither he pointed, and saw a white spot moving at an acute angle with the line taken by the leopardess.
column3: I looked whither he pointed, and saw a white spot moving at an acute angle with the line taken by the leopardess.

column2: There she is! he cried.
column3: There she is! he cried.

column2: The spotted leopardess is strong, but the white is stronger!
column3: The spotted leopardess is strong, but the white is stronger!

column2: I have seen them fight: the combat did not appear decisive as to that.
column3: I have seen them fight: the combat did not appear decisive as to that.

column2: How should such eyes tell which have never slept?	How should such eyes tell which have never slept?
column3: false

column2: The princess did not confess herself beaten--that she never does--but she fled!
column3: The princess did not confess herself beaten-that she never does-but she fled!

column2: When she confesses her last hope gone, that it is indeed hard to kick against the goad, then will her day begin to dawn!
column3: When she confesses her last hope gone, that it is indeed hard to kick against the goad, then will her day begin to dawn!

column2: Come; come!
column3: Come; come!

column2: He who cannot act must make haste to sleep!"
column3: He who cannot act must make haste to sleep!"

column2: CHAPTER XXXI.
column3: CHAPTER thirty one.

column2: THE SEXTON'S OLD HORSE
column3: THE SEXTON'S OLD HORSE

column2: I stood and watched the last gleam of the white leopardess melt away, then turned to follow my guide--but reluctantly.
column3: I stood and watched the last gleam of the white leopardess melt away, then turned to follow my guide-but reluctantly.

column2: What had I to do with sleep?
column3: What had I to do with sleep?

column2: Surely reason was the same in every world, and what reason could there be in going to sleep with the dead, when the hour was calling the live man?
column3: Surely reason was the same in every world, and what reason could there be in going to sleep with the dead, when the hour was calling the live man?

column2: Besides, no one would wake me, and how could I be certain of waking early--of waking at all?--the sleepers in that house let morning glide into noon, and noon into night, nor ever stirred!
column3: Besides, no one would wake me, and how could I be certain of waking early-of waking at all?--the sleepers in that house let morning glide into noon, and noon into night, nor ever stirred!

column2: I murmured, but followed, for I knew not what else to do.
column3: I murmured, but followed, for I knew not what else to do.

column2: The librarian walked on in silence, and I walked silent as he.
column3: The librarian walked on in silence, and I walked silent as he.

column2: Time and space glided past us.
column3: Time and space glided past us.

column2: The sun set; it began to grow dark, and I felt in the air the spreading cold of the chamber of death.
column3: The sun set; it began to grow dark, and I felt in the air the spreading cold of the chamber of death.

column2: My heart sank lower and lower.
column3: My heart sank lower and lower.

column2: I began to lose sight of the lean, long-coated figure, and at length could no more hear his swishing stride through the heather. But then I heard instead the slow-flapping wings of the raven; and, at intervals, now a firefly, now a gleaming butterfly rose into the rayless air.
column3: I began to lose sight of the lean, long coated figure, and at length could no more hear his swishing stride through the heather. But then I heard instead the slow flapping wings of the raven; and, at intervals, now a firefly, now a gleaming butterfly rose into the rayless air.

column2: By and by the moon appeared, slow crossing the far horizon.
column3: By and by the moon appeared, slow crossing the far horizon.

column2: You are tired, are you not, Mr. Vane? said the raven, alighting on a stone.
column3: You are tired, are you not, mr Vane? said the raven, alighting on a stone.

column2: You must make acquaintance with the horse that will carry you in the morning!
column3: You must make acquaintance with the horse that will carry you in the morning!

column2: He gave a strange whistle through his long black beak.
column3: He gave a strange whistle through his long black beak.

column2: A spot appeared on the face of the half-risen moon.
column3: A spot appeared on the face of the half risen moon.

column2: To my ears came presently the drumming of swift, soft-galloping hoofs, and in a minute or two, out of the very disc of the moon, low-thundered the terrible horse.
column3: To my ears came presently the drumming of swift, soft galloping hoofs, and in a minute or two, out of the very disc of the moon, low thundered the terrible horse.

column2: His mane flowed away behind him like the crest of a wind-fighting wave, torn seaward in hoary spray, and the whisk of his tail kept blinding the eye of the moon.
column3: His mane flowed away behind him like the crest of a wind fighting wave, torn seaward in hoary spray, and the whisk of his tail kept blinding the eye of the moon.

column2: Nineteen hands he seemed, huge of bone, tight of skin, hard of muscle--a steed the holy Death himself might choose on which to ride abroad and slay!
column3: Nineteen hands he seemed, huge of bone, tight of skin, hard of muscle-a steed the holy Death himself might choose on which to ride abroad and slay!

column2: The moon seemed to regard him with awe; in her scary light he looked a very skeleton, loosely roped together.
column3: The moon seemed to regard him with awe; in her scary light he looked a very skeleton, loosely roped together.

column2: Terrifically large, he moved with the lightness of a winged insect.
column3: Terrifically large, he moved with the lightness of a winged insect.

column2: As he drew near, his speed slackened, and his mane and tail drifted about him settling.
column3: As he drew near, his speed slackened, and his mane and tail drifted about him settling.

column2: Now I was not merely a lover of horses, but I loved every horse I saw. I had never spent money except upon horses, and had never sold a horse. The sight of this mighty one, terrible to look at, woke in me longing to possess him.
column3: Now I was not merely a lover of horses, but I loved every horse I saw. I had never spent money except upon horses, and had never sold a horse. The sight of this mighty one, terrible to look at, woke in me longing to possess him.

column2: It was pure greed, nay, rank covetousness, an evil thing in all the worlds.
column3: It was pure greed, nay, rank covetousness, an evil thing in all the worlds.

column2: I do not mean that I could have stolen him, but that, regardless of his proper place, I would have bought him if I could.
column3: I do not mean that I could have stolen him, but that, regardless of his proper place, I would have bought him if I could.

column2: I laid my hands on him, and stroked the protuberant bones that humped a hide smooth and thin, and shiny as satin--so shiny that the very shape of the moon was reflected in it; I fondled his sharp-pointed ears, whispered words in them, and breathed into his red nostrils the breath of a man's life.
column3: I laid my hands on him, and stroked the protuberant bones that humped a hide smooth and thin, and shiny as satin-so shiny that the very shape of the moon was reflected in it; I fondled his sharp pointed ears, whispered words in them, and breathed into his red nostrils the breath of a man's life.

column2: He in return breathed into mine the breath of a horse's life, and we loved one another.
column3: He in return breathed into mine the breath of a horse's life, and we loved one another.

column2: What eyes he had!
column3: What eyes he had!

column2: Blue-filmy like the eyes of the dead, behind each was a glowing coal!
column3: Blue filmy like the eyes of the dead, behind each was a glowing coal!

column2: The raven, with wings half extended, looked on pleased at my love-making to his magnificent horse.
column3: The raven, with wings half extended, looked on pleased at my love making to his magnificent horse.

column2: That is well! be friends with him, he said: "he will carry you all the better to-morrow!--Now we must hurry home!"
column3: That is well! be friends with him, he said: "he will carry you all the better to morrow!--Now we must hurry home!"

column2: My desire to ride the horse had grown passionate.
column3: My desire to ride the horse had grown passionate.

column2: May I not mount him at once, Mr. Raven? I cried.
column3: May I not mount him at once, mr Raven? I cried.

column2: By all means! he answered.
column3: By all means! he answered.

column2: Mount, and ride him home.
column3: Mount, and ride him home.

column2: The horse bent his head over my shoulder lovingly.
column3: The horse bent his head over my shoulder lovingly.

column2: I twisted my hands in his mane and scrambled onto his back, not without aid from certain protuberant bones.
column3: I twisted my hands in his mane and scrambled onto his back, not without aid from certain protuberant bones.

column2: He would outspeed any leopard in creation! I cried.
column3: He would outspeed any leopard in creation! I cried.

column2: Not that way at night, answered the raven; "the road is difficult.--But come; loss now will be gain then!
column3: Not that way at night, answered the raven; "the road is difficult.--But come; loss now will be gain then!

column2: To wait is harder than to run, and its meed is the fuller.
column3: To wait is harder than to run, and its meed is the fuller.

column2: Go on, my son--straight to the cottage.
column3: Go on, my son-straight to the cottage.

column2: I shall be there as soon as you.
column3: I shall be there as soon as you.

column2: It will rejoice my wife's heart to see son of hers on that horse!"
column3: It will rejoice my wife's heart to see son of hers on that horse!"

column2: I sat silent.
column3: I sat silent.

column2: The horse stood like a block of marble.
column3: The horse stood like a block of marble.

column2: Why do you linger? asked the raven.
column3: Why do you linger? asked the raven.

column2: I long so much to ride after the leopardess, I answered, "that I can scarce restrain myself!"
column3: I long so much to ride after the leopardess, I answered, "that I can scarce restrain myself!"

column2: You have promised!
column3: You have promised!

column2: My debt to the Little Ones appears, I confess, a greater thing than my bond to you.
column3: My debt to the Little Ones appears, I confess, a greater thing than my bond to you.

column2: Yield to the temptation and you will bring mischief upon them--and on yourself also.
column3: Yield to the temptation and you will bring mischief upon them-and on yourself also.

column2: What matters it for me?	What matters it for me?
column3: false

column2: I love them; and love works no evil.
column3: I love them; and love works no evil.

column2: I will go."
column3: I will go."

column2: But the truth was, I forgot the children, infatuate with the horse.
column3: But the truth was, I forgot the children, infatuate with the horse.

column2: Eyes flashed through the darkness, and I knew that Adam stood in his own shape beside me.
column3: Eyes flashed through the darkness, and I knew that Adam stood in his own shape beside me.

column2: I knew also by his voice that he repressed an indignation almost too strong for him.
column3: I knew also by his voice that he repressed an indignation almost too strong for him.

column2: Mr. Vane, he said, "do you not know why you have not yet done anything worth doing?"
column3: mr Vane, he said, "do you not know why you have not yet done anything worth doing?"

column2: Because I have been a fool, I answered.
column3: Because I have been a fool, I answered.

column2: Wherein?
column3: Wherein?

column2: In everything.
column3: In everything.

column2: Which do you count your most indiscreet action?
column3: Which do you count your most indiscreet action?

column2: Bringing the princess to life: I ought to have left her to her just fate.
column3: Bringing the princess to life: I ought to have left her to her just fate.

column2: Nay, now you talk foolishly!	Nay, now you talk foolishly!
column3: true

column2: You could not have done otherwise than you did, not knowing she was evil!--But you never brought any one to life! How could you, yourself dead?"
column3: You could not have done otherwise than you did, not knowing she was evil!--But you never brought any one to life! How could you, yourself dead?"

column2: I dead? I cried.
column3: I dead? I cried.

column2: Yes, he answered; "and you will be dead, so long as you refuse to die."
column3: Yes, he answered; "and you will be dead, so long as you refuse to die."

column2: Back to the old riddling! I returned scornfully.
column3: Back to the old riddling! I returned scornfully.

column2: Be persuaded, and go home with me, he continued gently.
column3: Be persuaded, and go home with me, he continued gently.

column2: The most--nearly the only foolish thing you ever did, was to run from our dead.
column3: The most-nearly the only foolish thing you ever did, was to run from our dead.

column2: I pressed the horse's ribs, and he was off like a sudden wind.
column3: I pressed the horse's ribs, and he was off like a sudden wind.

column2: I gave him a pat on the side of the neck, and he went about in a sharp-driven curve, "close to the ground, like a cat when scratchingly she wheels about after a mouse," leaning sideways till his mane swept the tops of the heather.
column3: I gave him a pat on the side of the neck, and he went about in a sharp driven curve, "close to the ground, like a cat when scratchingly she wheels about after a mouse," leaning sideways till his mane swept the tops of the heather.

column2: Through the dark I heard the wings of the raven.
column3: Through the dark I heard the wings of the raven.

column2: Five quick flaps I heard, and he perched on the horse's head.
column3: Five quick flaps I heard, and he perched on the horse's head.

column2: The horse checked himself instantly, ploughing up the ground with his feet.
column3: The horse checked himself instantly, ploughing up the ground with his feet.

column2: Mr. Vane, croaked the raven, "think what you are doing!
column3: mr Vane, croaked the raven, "think what you are doing!

column2: Twice already has evil befallen you--once from fear, and once from heedlessness: breach of word is far worse; it is a crime."
column3: Twice already has evil befallen you-once from fear, and once from heedlessness: breach of word is far worse; it is a crime."

column2: The Little Ones are in frightful peril, and I brought it upon them! I cried.
column3: The Little Ones are in frightful peril, and I brought it upon them! I cried.

column2: --But indeed I will not break my word to you.	--But indeed I will not break my word to you.
column3: true

column2: I will return, and spend in your house what nights--what days--what years you please."
column3: I will return, and spend in your house what nights-what days-what years you please."

column2: I tell you once more you will do them other than good if you go to-night, he insisted.
column3: I tell you once more you will do them other than good if you go to night, he insisted.

column2: But a false sense of power, a sense which had no root and was merely vibrated into me from the strength of the horse, had, alas, rendered me too stupid to listen to anything he said!
column3: But a false sense of power, a sense which had no root and was merely vibrated into me from the strength of the horse, had, alas, rendered me too stupid to listen to anything he said!

column2: Would you take from me my last chance of reparation? I cried.
column3: Would you take from me my last chance of reparation? I cried.

column2: This time there shall be no shirking!	This time there shall be no shirking!
column3: true

column2: It is my duty, and I will go--if I perish for it!"
column3: It is my duty, and I will go-if I perish for it!"

column2: Go, then, foolish boy! he returned, with anger in his croak.
column3: Go, then, foolish boy! he returned, with anger in his croak.

column2: Take the horse, and ride to failure!	Take the horse, and ride to failure!
column3: true

column2: May it be to humility!"
column3: May it be to humility!"

column2: He spread his wings and flew.
column3: He spread his wings and flew.

column2: Again I pressed the lean ribs under me.
column3: Again I pressed the lean ribs under me.

column2: After the spotted leopardess! I whispered in his ear.
column3: After the spotted leopardess! I whispered in his ear.

column2: He turned his head this way and that, snuffing the air; then started, and went a few paces in a slow, undecided walk.
column3: He turned his head this way and that, snuffing the air; then started, and went a few paces in a slow, undecided walk.

column2: Suddenly he quickened his walk; broke into a trot; began to gallop, and in a few moments his speed was tremendous.
column3: Suddenly he quickened his walk; broke into a trot; began to gallop, and in a few moments his speed was tremendous.

column2: He seemed to see in the dark; never stumbled, not once faltered, not once hesitated.
column3: He seemed to see in the dark; never stumbled, not once faltered, not once hesitated.

column2: I sat as on the ridge of a wave.
column3: I sat as on the ridge of a wave.

column2: I felt under me the play of each individual muscle: his joints were so elastic, and his every movement glided so into the next, that not once did he jar me.
column3: I felt under me the play of each individual muscle: his joints were so elastic, and his every movement glided so into the next, that not once did he jar me.

column2: His growing swiftness bore him along until he flew rather than ran.
column3: His growing swiftness bore him along until he flew rather than ran.

column2: The wind met and passed us like a tornado.
column3: The wind met and passed us like a tornado.

column2: Across the evil hollow we sped like a bolt from an arblast.
column3: Across the evil hollow we sped like a bolt from an arblast.

column2: No monster lifted its neck; all knew the hoofs that thundered over their heads!
column3: No monster lifted its neck; all knew the hoofs that thundered over their heads!

column2: We rushed up the hills, we shot down their farther slopes; from the rocky chasms of the river-bed he did not swerve; he held on over them his fierce, terrible gallop.
column3: We rushed up the hills, we shot down their farther slopes; from the rocky chasms of the river bed he did not swerve; he held on over them his fierce, terrible gallop.

column2: The moon, half-way up the heaven, gazed with a solemn trouble in her pale countenance.
column3: The moon, half-way up the heaven, gazed with a solemn trouble in her pale countenance.

column2: Rejoicing in the power of my steed and in the pride of my life, I sat like a king and rode.
column3: Rejoicing in the power of my steed and in the pride of my life, I sat like a king and rode.

column2: We were near the middle of the many channels, my horse every other moment clearing one, sometimes two in his stride, and now and then gathering himself for a great bounding leap, when the moon reached the key-stone of her arch.
column3: We were near the middle of the many channels, my horse every other moment clearing one, sometimes two in his stride, and now and then gathering himself for a great bounding leap, when the moon reached the key stone of her arch.

column2: Then came a wonder and a terror: she began to descend rolling like the nave of Fortune's wheel bowled by the gods, and went faster and faster.
column3: Then came a wonder and a terror: she began to descend rolling like the nave of Fortune's wheel bowled by the gods, and went faster and faster.

column2: Like our own moon, this one had a human face, and now the broad forehead now the chin was uppermost as she rolled.
column3: Like our own moon, this one had a human face, and now the broad forehead now the chin was uppermost as she rolled.

column2: I gazed aghast.
column3: I gazed aghast.

column2: Across the ravines came the howling of wolves.
column3: Across the ravines came the howling of wolves.

column2: An ugly fear began to invade the hollow places of my heart; my confidence was on the wane!
column3: An ugly fear began to invade the hollow places of my heart; my confidence was on the wane!

column2: The horse maintained his headlong swiftness, with ears pricked forward, and thirsty nostrils exulting in the wind his career created.
column3: The horse maintained his headlong swiftness, with ears pricked forward, and thirsty nostrils exulting in the wind his career created.

column2: But there was the moon jolting like an old chariot-wheel down the hill of heaven, with awful boding!
column3: But there was the moon jolting like an old chariot wheel down the hill of heaven, with awful boding!

column2: She rolled at last over the horizon-edge and disappeared, carrying all her light with her.
column3: She rolled at last over the horizon edge and disappeared, carrying all her light with her.

column2: The mighty steed was in the act of clearing a wide shallow channel when we were caught in the net of the darkness.
column3: The mighty steed was in the act of clearing a wide shallow channel when we were caught in the net of the darkness.

column2: His head dropped; its impetus carried his helpless bulk across, but he fell in a heap on the margin, and where he fell he lay.
column3: His head dropped; its impetus carried his helpless bulk across, but he fell in a heap on the margin, and where he fell he lay.

column2: I got up, kneeled beside him, and felt him all over.
column3: I got up, kneeled beside him, and felt him all over.

column2: Not a bone could I find broken, but he was a horse no more.
column3: Not a bone could I find broken, but he was a horse no more.

column2: I sat down on the body, and buried my face in my hands.
column3: I sat down on the body, and buried my face in my hands.
